The Drúadan language referred to the ton: The voices of the Drúedain are said to have been "deep and guttural"
p. 99: possibly also describing the sound of their language as Ghân-buri-Ghâns accent when using Westron is described with the very same words.

The Drúadan language referred to the ton: Helge Fauskanger has noted that the Drúadan tongue appears to be unrelated to the Westron. According to a late manuscript by J.R.R. Tolkien
p. 99: it had possibly been influenced by Elvish (at least for the word gorgûn).

The Drúadan language referred to the ton: In a manuscript by Tolkien written in the late 1950s
p. 99: he uses the name Druadan (also referring to a member of the Drúedain in The Lord of the Rings; amended to Drúadan in the second edition) for the language of the Woses.

The Drúadan language referred to the ton: This seems to be the only occurrence where Tolkien uses a name for this tongue: since the manuscript was published as late as 2007
p. 99: fans and scholars have often used the unattested name Drúedainic to refer to the same tongue.Helge Fauskanger
